Posts.Content: Nov 11, 2014 12:37AM momoschki wrote: I too was found to have a small area of ADH almost 4 years ago after a stereotactic biopsy. Afterwards, I underwent an excisional biopsy (lumpectomy), which I understand is usually standard procedure. The rationale for this is to make sure that the ADH is not obscuring something more serious-- usually DCIS. This occurs in about 20% of cases. So yes, while the ADH itself is benign, it's important to remove it to make sure that nothing more ominous lurking. As others have pointed out, the "chemo prevention" your doctor mentioned refers to preventive meds for women at high risk-- tamoxifen, or, evista or aromatase inhibitors for those who are post-menopausal. This is NOT the usual "chemo" we hear about women with BC getting. These meds are usually then for 5 years Fwiw, when I received my dx, my breast surgeon, who is the head of the department at a prominent NYC hospital, said quite adamantly that mastectomy was not indicated at all. Perhaps this would be different if you had a strong family hx and/or were BRCA +, but that's not your situation. I do think that the excisional biopsy is completely appropriate, however. After that, if hopefully all you are dealing with is the ADH (which is the most likely outcome), then meeting with an oncologist can help you to better understand your personal risk and what your prevention/monitoring options are.

Posts.Content: Apr 24, 2014 08:31PM momoschki wrote: Helen, My understanding is that the excisional biopsy is done primarily to ensure that there is no cancer obscured by the atypia and that clean margins are not the objective, as they are for an actual cancer dx.  Removing the area of atypia is the standard of treatment and the atypia (whether ADH or ALH) is considered a marker for heightened risk of BC in the future (even if it is all surgically removed.). So, in the event you do have it removed, you will most likely be put on a 6 month high risk rotation of mammos, ultrasound, and MRI's. Anyway, this has been my experience after a dx of ADH 3 years ago.  You may also be offered some form of hormonal treatment as a preventive measure.  Personally, I would not have been comfortable not having the surgery.   Feel free to ask anymore questions you may have-- unfortunately, I feel like I have gained quite a but if knowledge on this topic over the past few years...

Posts.Content: Apr 10, 2016 09:56PM momoschki wrote: And further update: From a follow up email concerning potential testing of Ki67 as a predictor of BC risk in postmenopausal women (I'm quoting directly): We did test normal breast biopsies from postmenopausal women also, but Ki67 was not predictive of risk in this group. Most likely because the level of Ki67+ cells reflects hormone-induced proliferation of breast cells and after menopause there is much less of this. But, may be testing a larger cohort and more sensitive assays can change this, although knowing your risk at younger age could help with setting up more personalized screening strategies. Ideally we would like to eliminate these proliferating cells, so then we could decrease breast cancer incidence. I really hope that some of the strategies we are trying out now will work. We will see...  So-- that clarified the pre/post-menopausal question

Posts.Content: Jun 5, 2017 12:17PM - edited Jun 5, 2017 12:19PM by momoschki You can request that the institution where you had the US biopsy done forward your slides to another hospital. It's not the reports you want read elsewhere, it's the slides with the actual tissue samples. I wonder, though, if it would make sense to wait until you have the excisional, as perhaps it may reveal something more conclusive? Regardless of whether the conclusion of the needle biopsy is ADH, DCIS, or something "borderline", the next step would be the excisional procedure anyway. In the beginning, I was very caught up in nailing down exactly what I had in there-- cancer or not cancer? Over time (6.5 years) it bothers me less. Keep in mind that the whole DCIS/ADH diagnostic process is along a continuum, not a clear cut dichotomy. Whatever I had catapulted me into the high risk category, unfortunately. And yes, I would agree that your family hx has to be factored in. Has anyone suggested genetic testing? Hang in there and press for the answers you want. One thing I definitely learned throughout this experience is that you have to advocate for yourself! Sadly, that's especially difficult when you are hit with something as stressful and scary as this

Posts.Content: Mar 7, 2013 10:26AM - edited Mar 7, 2013 04:10PM by momoschki While I was never diagnosed with sclerosing adenosis, it seems like the work of pathologists is often rather subjective and there can be lots if disagreement in murky areas. After a stereotactic biopsy 2 years ago, the initial dx was DCIS. However, when I chose a breast surgeon to consult with who was from a different hospital from the first where my slides were initially analyzed, she wanted them looked at again by the pathologists at hospital #2-- dx was downgraded to borderline DCIS/ADH. When I chose an oncologist from yet a third hospital, he insisted my slides be looked at a third time(!) by hospital #3-- dx was now pure ADH. So, you see, there can be considerable disagreement, and this was at 3 major highly respected facilities in NYC. Bottom line: don't be afraid to get a second (or even a third) opinion. Pathology reading is often not such a clear cut, black and white business.

Posts.Content: May 8, 2012 09:05AM momoschki wrote: Jaye, Yes, I was dx'ed with ADH in February of last year and am doing many things differently.  Ramped up my exercise program and have lost 10 lbs, have greatly cut back on my wine drinking (my to my displeasure!), cut practically all the meat out of my diet (altho I was not eating that much to begin with), and try to by organic fruits/veggies when possible.  I am seeing an integrative oncologist who has me on a number of supplements and tests my blood 2x year for various markers/levels.  I see my BS 2x year as well, and she follows up with mammos, US, and MRI's, so I am always getting scanned every 6 month.  This is incredibly nerve racking, but also reassuring.  Probably the most radical and controversial thing I did was to get a breast reduction after reading a body of research (mostly out of Canada and Scandanavia) that showed that women who had had substantial amounts of breast tissue removed, especially those who were over 50 (I am now 54), had decreased incidence of BS.  I found a PS who believed in this research, although it is largely either unknown or dismissed (my BS pooh-poohed it), and is part of an oncoloplastic team that routinely does such surgeries.  For me, it seemed like there was no downside. This Dx felt like a sword dangling over my head and I really felt the need to do something-- not just to be passive.  Whether everything I have done will prove effective remains to be seen-- no guarantees, for sure.  Good luck to you!

Posts.Content: Aug 30, 2011 01:00PM momoschki wrote: Chicken, I have no real wisdom to share with you other than to say I am in the same boat.  Dx'ed with ADH this Feb.  I am 54.  No family Hx, no other particular risk factors.  Remember that the 4-5X increased rate of BC occurence is not calculated from the 12% risk the "average" woman has, but rather from the theoretical woman with no risk factors, so in my case, I was told my risk over the next 15 years is somewhere between 20 and 25%.  It's still scary, and you are absolutely right-- it does feel like a mental disorder.  It's hard not to think about anything else, but nevertheless, here is how I have dealt with it so far: 1.  This doesn't sound like I viable option for you, being small breasted, but I had a prophylactic breast reduction done by an oncoplastic team here in NYC.  This procedure is not well known or endorsed by the general medical community, but there is promising research from Europe and Canada.  No guarantees, of course, but my surgeon thought it reduced my risk in the neighborhood of 50%.  Went from a D to a B cup. 2.  I started seeing an integrative oncologist.  In my case, he determined that tamoxifen or evista would only reduce my relative risk about 4%, so it didn't seem worth risking the SE's , IMO.  This doctor has me on many supplements, so I am hopeful that they will have a further preventive effect. 3.  I started seeing a psychiatrist.  This was especially helpful at the beginning stages of Dx and all the angst and anxiety which accompanies that.  I also decided that meds were in order:  Klonopin for anxiety (I wasn't sleeping at all at night--- now I sleep very well), and just last week, we decided to add a low dose of an antidepressant, since it seemed like my level of upset was just not propotional with my circumstances.  Too soon to say whether that is working, since I have only been taking it for 5 days. 4,  My breast surgeon was vehement at this point that I was NOT a candidate for a PBMX (I had only one very small lesion of ADH which was totally removed by the needle biopsy-- excisional biopsy and path report from the reduction surgery came back totally clean), but if, down the road, I had repeated biopsies, more ADH (or worse), I would go down the mastectomy road just not to have to worry about it anymore.  Of course, I would like to avoid that, but I have to see how the 6 month checks go.  First one is in November, and I am already nervous..  Anyway, you should have a clearer picture about how to proceed once you have the excisional biopsy.  I think that now you are in the most difficult part of this whole nasty process-- lots of uncertainty about the future and not knowing what your game plan is yet.  As many have said before me, it is very likely that once you know what's what diagnostically and have a Tx plan in place, you will feel somewhat better.

Posts.Content: Jun 23, 2018 02:12PM momoschki wrote: Elsa, yes, your biopsy findings are benign, but surgical consultation is indicated because ADH is generally removed. It’s possible that the needle biopsy did not remove the entire area, and in addition, the excisional biopsy (essentially lumpectomy) is wise because in about 20% of cases, DCIS or IDC is found. So the needle biopsy results may possibly not be the whole story (although the odds are definitely in your favor), and in that sense your pathology results are not yet final. In terms of future treatment, there will usually be increased screenings (every six months), with some combo of mammograms, MRIs and perhaps ultrasounds. There are also preventive med options that can increase your chances of remaining cancer free: tamoxifen, raloxifene , or an aromatase inhibitor (the latter 2 if you are post-menopausal). After you get your excisional biopsy results, a consult with an oncologist can be helpful. Feel free to PM me if you have more questions- I’ve been dealing with this for over 7 years.

Posts.Content: Mar 18, 2014 02:25PM momoschki wrote: This topic generates a lot if controversy in the medical world.  I had a bilateral reduction after reading some research, mostly done in Canada and Scandinavia, that showed reduced occurrence of BC after surgical reductions.  I will try to dig up the citations and post them here later.  The risk reducing effect was more pronounced in older women (I think I remember 45+ being considered "older"), also the greater the amount of tissue removed, the greater the risk reduction. I suspect that many hospitals do not have oncoplastic teams, which is really too bad, since reductions could be offered as a viable option for many women as something midway between a lumpectomy and a mastectomy.  Both my PS and onc estimated I cut my risk somewhere in the neighborhood of 50%. Posts.Content: Sep 29, 2017 05:02PM - edited Sep 29, 2017 05:04PM by momoschki Patti May, when your ADH is classified as focally severe, I believe this refers to the histology, not the number of foci. ADH and DCIS run along a continuum and distinguishing between them can be tricky and often rather subjective, so a focally severe ADH lesion would be one that borders on meeting the criteria of DCIS. (I am pretty sure of this-- perhaps someone can chime in and confirm this?). If you had more than one focus of ADH, that would be multi focal. FWIW, when I was dx'ed I got 3 opinions from 3 different hospitals on my pathology from the needle biopsy: the first said dcis, the second classified it as ADH bordering on DCIS (in other words, severe ADH) and the third said just ADH. Both the oncologist and the breast surgeon I saw (and continue to see) said it didn't make a difference from a prognostic point of view. It was only one tiny focus

Posts.Content: Feb 20, 2013 09:20PM momoschki wrote: Rainey, I can so identify with many of your feelings. Two years ago I felt totally blindsided when a routine mammogram found micro -calcifications that required a biopsy. I felt like I was Alice falling down the rabbit hole. I was over 20 years older than you are and, as many others here have said, your age definitely counts in your favor. And btw, in my case, the result was not cancer, but pre -malignant tissue, which was removed. But, more importantly, although I can certainly understand that you are overwhelmed and terrified now, I would urge you to put your phone back together again! My rationale is this: so long as the phone is dismantled, you cannot receive information that has an approx 80% chance of offering you relief-- so, as long as you prevent yourself from getting those results, you leave yourself in a painful limbo where you can only imagine catastrophic results. It is an awful situation to be in, to be sure, but you need to hear the facts so that you can breathe a huge sigh of relief and end your torture, or, in the unlikely (20%) case of the news you don't want, you can move forward. Sending all the best wishes . Hang in there-- we all know the particular brand of agony you are in the middle of now.

Posts.Content: Mar 1, 2014 09:00PM - edited Mar 1, 2014 10:35PM by momoschki This is a controversial topic.  When I got an ADH dx, I decided to have a bilateral reduction because of some literature I had read (from Europe & Canada) that showed that women who had reductions had a lower incidence of BC than women in the group that had not.  Luckily, I found a great oncoplastic team that believes in the validity of this procedure from a prophylactic prospective.  Still, my BS (another hospital, same city) was very dismissive.  I think the rationale is  that as breast tissue is removed (the glandular tissue, not the fat), it thereby reduces the probability of that tissue becoming cancerous. I had my first mammogram 6 months after the surgery to get a new baseline. Anyway, I think that if you had a substantial reduction, it is fair to assume that some if the ducts were removed?  Ask your PS for clarification.  How much tissue was removed?  I went from a 34D to a 34B.  Both my PS and onc believe that this reduces my risk somewhere in the neighborhood of 50%-- sure hope they're right! (Btw, I also developed a small hole about 3 weeks post op at the junction where the IMF met the vertical incision.  I was told this is quite common.  I kept it covered with gauze and Neosporin and it healed completely after a week or so.)

Posts.Content: momoschki wrote: I am 53 and have had yearly mammograms, almost always with callbacks for additional views and ultrasounds, due to dense tissue.  However, up until this year, I have been told all was normal and that I should return the following year. Last week, however, the radiologist doing the US informed me that she saw additional microcalcifications that she had not seen the previous year (I did have some last year that she wasn't at all concerned about.)  Because of these new developments, she told me I would need a biopsy (scheduled for this Tuesday).  She did mention that she didn't think it would turn out to be malignant, and that I shouldn't worry-- she said she was just recommending this because it was "good medicine."  She never offered a BI-RADS rating, and I didn't think to ask until reading about them here after the fact.  I am assuming that the rating must be a 4, otherwise she would not have ordered the biopsy in the first place.  Later that day, my gyne called me at home, after receiving a fax of these latest developments, and also told me that I shouldn't worry, that she doesn't think this will turn out to be anything.  I am finding all these conflicting messages extremely confusing:  biopsy on the one hand;  2 separate doctors on the other, telling me "don't worry".  I know all the stats about 80% of biopsies turning out benign, but I am having a great deal of trouble thinking why I shouldn't end up in that unlucky 20%.  Additionally, even if the results do turn out benign this time, it seems to me that I may well be in for trouble in the future.  No cancer history in the family, but that is no real comfort.  I need talking off the ledge here-- I am feeling totally unraveled and dissolve into tears unpredictably at the drop of a hat.  Any words of wisdom to offer from those more experienced?   ADH dx 3/11 Surgery 3/10/2011 Lumpectomy: Left Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Feb 27, 2011 08:02PM momoschki wrote: Just bumping this thread up again with an additional question, uncovered by my continued compulsive researching.  I still need to wait for my excisional biopsy on the 8th to determine, definitively, if I am dealing with ADH, DCIS, or a mixture of the two, but in the meantime, I seem to have uncovered some legitimate sounding research, some of it originating from Sweden and Ontario, among other places, that demonstrates that high risk women can significantly cut their risk of future cancer occurrences by undergoing breast reductions.  It seems that the reduction of future risk is directly related to the amount of tissue removed, and can potentially cut future risk by as much as 50%.  If it turns out that I am dealing with pure ADH, I wonder if this could be a potential way for me to go... less drastic than PBMX's, but more proactive than the "careful surveillance" (i.e.," let's keep an eye on you until you do develop cancer" route.)  Since I am already a 34D, I could happily live with a lot less on top. Just wondering if anyone has any additional information/experience regarding this.  It appears that the reduction of risk is directly related to the amount of the removal of glandular tissue, which makes sense to me.  Neither my breast surgeon, nor the plastic surgeon whom  I visited in possible anticipation of the PBMX, mentioned anything to me about this possible option.

Posts.Content: Jun 7, 2012 01:48PM momoschki wrote: Thanks for everyone's responses.  Just to follow up:  I now have a consensus among my gyno, MO, and a naturopath with whom I occasionally consult.  All 3 agree that the amount of estrogen absorbed systemically is insignificant and the MO and ND think the best option is the Vagifem, used 2X week.  Both the MO and ND also think this is good prevention against potential atrophy and prolapse.  So why do I still feel so wary about going ahead?  As I understand it, the issue is not merely increasing lubrication, but also help in plumping up tissues and improving elasticity (which olive oil will not do, not other OTC lubricants.)

Posts.Content: Feb 19, 2011 06:08PM momoschki wrote: Ugh... I just wrote a lengthy and detailed response here, which somehow disappeared... With the DCIS Dx (when I thought that was accurate, 2 days ago!) I did a lot of research, spoke with both my breast surgeon and a plastic surgeon whom she often teams up with, and decided to go the route of a skin/nipple sparing BMX with  an immediate reconstruction.  I think I was fully aware of the gravity of the choice and everything it entailed-- still, I felt confident, after researching it, speaking to my doctors, and talking to friends and family who know me well, that this was the best route for me, from both a medical and a psychological point of view.  I simply could not imagine choosing a more conservative Tx plan and then worrying about something reemerging.  With the DCIS Dx, as terrifying and shocking as the cancer Dx was, I felt like I dodged a huge bullet by being able to avoid chemo. Now that I have told close friends and family about the likely diagnostic change, everyone is congratulating me and telling me to celebrate, but I feel quite the opposite.  While it is unquestionably good that I do not have cancer now, I feel like now I must be watched and monitored in a way that will make me crazy and anxious, and that if I do end up with a BC Dx, there is of course the chance that it could be invasive (which, at least, the DCIS was not.)  My doctor is now planning a lumpectomy on 3/8, and while I am relieved at not having to face massive surgery so soon, she says she would refuse to do the BMX if the current diagnosis of ADH is confirmed by the lumpectomy results.  Of course, I respect her medical opinion, but the "solution" that I had found for myself, as imperfect as it was, is now off the table... Just feeling very confused about what all this will mean for my future and feel that if BC is in my future (some studies I have read put it as an increased risk of about 400%), I would much prefer to get it all over with now, rather than be paralyzed with fear every 6 months.  We'll see what the breast surgeon has to say when I meet with her this Wednesday, but for the present, while everyone is happy and congratulating me, I feel oddly worse.

Reading the experiences from so many women here, it seems like this is so often not the case.  I am still needing to get details from the report that at the time of the conversation yesterday, I was too dazed to remember to ask.  But I get the impression here that many women have eventually ended up with mastectomies following muliple lumpectomies due to all kinds of surprises:  dirty margins, multi-focal lesions, unexpected discoveries of more invasive cancer.  It sounds far more complicated than I might have been led to believe just a couple of days ago.

Posts.Content: Jun 26, 2017 04:23PM momoschki wrote: Mastectomy is typically not recommended for a dx of ADH. I think it's natural that our first reaction is fear and "off with them!" in an attempt to put all this behind us. Keep in mind that usually the mammo and MRI will alternate every 6 months, so you will be gettIng no more radiation than someone on a regular screening schedule. Have you seen an oncologist who can give you a good estimation of your own personal risk? Also, not everyone who takes tamoxifen has terrible side effects. Ifyou are post menopausal, there are other options.
Posts.Title: Atypical ductal hyperplasia: mastectomy Mlezak MTwoman

Posts.Content: Jun 25, 2013 05:55PM momoschki wrote: While I did not have a cancer dx, a biopsy showed ADH in my case, which was removed via excisional biopsy.  My breast surgeon said no further treatment was required, but being the worried and paranoid type that I am, i did some research on my own on breast reduction, which some European and Canadian studies have shown to reduce the incidence of BC.  Being large breasted, this seemed like a no brainer to me.  I wish I had had better timing so that I could have had only one surgery-- I had the lumpectomy first, followed by the bilateral reduction 3 months later. While the first week post-surgery was painful (sleeping comfortably was a challenge), by and large, the whole ordeal was a good deal easier than I expected.  I did not have trouble raising my hands above my head, had no drains, and was able to shower 48 hours later.  I was back doing 35 mile bike rides 3 weeks afterwards (with a sturdy sports bra!) and used the silicone gel strips for scarring.  It is now a little over 2 years later and the scars are really almost invisible. As for the cosmetic results, I couldn't have been more pleased.  I went from a 34D to a 34B.  As I am pretty active and athletic, it's liberating not having to drag the big boobs around, and I love that I can wear things now that weren't possible before.  I am much more proportional. I wish more people knew about this as an option.  For anyone in the NYC area, NY Presbyterian Weill Cornell has a great team.  I would highly recommend them.  But what's disheartening is that my BS, who is at NYU and did the excisional biopsy was highly dismissive of this procedure-- one done at another top notch hospital less than 2 miles away.

Posts.Content: Mar 3, 2014 02:39PM momoschki wrote: Kimberly, Glad you got a definitive answer to your questions.  There has also got to be somewhere on the report where the surgeon states just how many grams of tissue were removed, to get even more exact.
